Nice flex big guy (go bears)
Come now no need for this, we all are trying our best
This is why I'm transferring to a private school next year. Ridiculous.

similar situation

history.content:
CS 164 had spots open when I enrolled this morning back - it's certainly not easy, but will definitely improve your skill as a programmer by working on such a large project.

Waitlisting for CS 161 might also be a decent idea, you'd have very good (~70-90% depending on what discussion you waitlist for) to get into

CS 174 is actually open at this point, and might be a good idea if you were looking to take 126 but couldn't (they're not the same, but 174 will certainly help with probabilistic maturity); you might have decent chances of getting into 188 as well.

Aside from that, maybe look into some Tech electives (IEOR, Math, Stats)? I know you can't enroll into Math 104/110/185/113/128A in Phase 1, but maybe look at classes like Math 115 (Number Theory), or Stat 135/133? If you're looking for lower-div classes, consider Phil 12A (Intro to logic) or IB C32 (Bio-inspired design).

I can understand your frustration (I'm in exactly this situation right now, and certainly think we need to take a hard look at a situation where even juniors are having trouble getting into any upper divs, let alone sophomores), but these are a few options as stated above; if anyone else has other elective/upper-div suggestions, please put them below?

Waitlisting for CS 161 might also be a decent idea, you'd have very good (~70-90% depending on what discussion you waitlist for) to get into

Aside from that, maybe look into some Tech electives (IEOR, Math, Stats)? I know you can't enroll into Math 104/110/185/113/128A in Phase 1, but maybe look at classes like Math 115 (Number Theory), or Stat 135/133?

children.subject: @Vyom Kavishwar Thank you, I appreciate your response. None of those classes are of interest to me/in my priority list before I graduate (I will have already taken 188, it was cool), but I hope it helps someone else in this position.
+1 to all points

What is the point of putting pressure on the school? The department is already doing what it can. I also disagree with the phrase "the admins have somewhat underestimated the sheer interest that this field has attracted..." because the enrollment in 126 was perfectly manageable last semester. This is not a trend that the department is unaware of/has been ignoring, it's pretty much started now.

Well, the last time Ramchandran taught EE126 (sp17), the course also was full during the first week of enrollment (see @2499). It filled up a bit faster this semester, but not by much.

That is, the fact that the course filled up quickly isn't much of a surprise.

You two are missing the point. This isn't about EE126/7. Some students including me are having huge issues getting into any upper divs next semester. What are we supposed to do? I'm taking my last lower div next semester and transferring out.
...I mean, I just checked every single CS/EECS upper div that I took as a student (including EE126), and every one of them has a lecture with more open seats than people on the waitlist.
Bruh thats because the waitlist is full already. 126 has 23 reserve spots and 20 waitlist capacity.

You all make some great points, let's remember to stay respectful to each other. I somewhat agree with Sinho's points. The department is already under severe pressure and we should avoid making their lives harder. Maybe we should have a townhall meeting to discuss issues concerning demand and enrollment.

Let me make this clear: I am not trying to place all the blame on the school or department. I just think we are in an unfortunate situation that seems to be getting worse and worse every semester. This semester it may not be an issue, but if the tech industry continues to grow like it is doing today, UC Berkeley needs to find a way to address the exponential growth in demand for eecs. The eecs department, and UC Berkeley for that manner, cannot remain a top notch university if it cannot meet the demands of its students. I think we call all agree on this point?

Simply because we are only marginally more constrained with enrollment this semester doesn't excuse the problem that people are super stressed about getting into the classes they want. This is a real problem, how are we going to fix it? Should students just give up and stop speaking out? I don't think that's an effective strategy.

Make your voice heard! Obviously, I think the department is doing the best they can to accommodate all the demand, but I think working with the constraints they have is truly unsustainable in the long run. Obviously they are in a super tough spot so give them some room and approach them with a respectful tone. 

Some students have made a lot of posts recently about enrollment issues, particularly regarding the ML/Stat classes. In my view, the admins have somewhat underestimated the sheer interest that this field has attracted over the last couple years. I think ML/Stats classes have the highest interest/demand (for the better or worse) and much more resources needs to be allocated there. With prof. Sahai telling students to take EECS 126/127 before 189, we need to make sure to increase the capacity of 126 and 127 to at least 200 and above. However, there is perhaps a reason why they are limiting the enrollment: 126 and 127 enrollment usually drops like a rock once some students realize that they cannot keep up with the level of rigor in these classes. So to those people interested in 126/127 who can't even get on the waitlist, stay hopeful. Somehow it ends up working out every semester. It's quite a mess but it ends up working out.

Personally, I am planning on writing a blog post about this issue in the future. It's a real problem that is making an otherwise fantastic school like Berkeley look really unappealing. I don't like to advertise UC Berkeley as a bad place, but the hope is that by speaking out we can place enough pressure on the school to the point that they have to respond. 

Lastly, I'd like to make a personal call to expand CS 194-129. It's not fair that only seniors/regents people can get in the class.

I totally agree with you, this seems like a really poor decision. This is giving more leeway to seniors and juniors, and sophomores and freshmen are left in the dust. I feel as if a good portion of people are trying to enroll in 3 techs, and most students with very high probability will drop one of them. So that's at least reassuring to think about.

I'd like to add that not even juniors are unscathed from this decision - juniors with later appointments (today or Tuesday) are just as screwed, especially because we have already taken a fair few classes and thus the number of classes we want to (and can take) are significantly lower.

The whole issue is that the current enrolment system ensures that anyone with a later appointment gets the scraps of what's left after the people with the early appointments have enrolled into 13.5 units; an example of this issue was with CS 194-129, which filled up at a ridiculously quick rate, to the point that no one with a later appointment could even dream of getting in off the waitlist, let alone enrolling into the class.

The system needs to stop leaving important decisions like taking classes to the luck of the draw (in terms of appointment timings), and come up with a better way to optimise so every student gets into at least one first-choice class they want in Phase 1 (a 170 final project, perhaps? :p)

+1 @vyom

(junior here, literally wasn't able to phase 1 a single class upper div that I planned to)

This was a decision made at the campus level (probably by a committee of deans).

I think it is fair to say that I haven't met anyone among the department staff who thinks it was a good decision or that it was implemented well.  The claim is that it is better for students but there has been no attempt to explain how or why they think it is better for any student.

+1 @vyom @Anon above

 

(Another junior here, also wasn't able to phase 1 a single class upper div that I planned to)
I think part of the problem that classes are so full so early in phase 1 is because the phase 1 unit cap was increased to 13.5. Does anyone know why the school decided on this change last semester?

history.content:
1,  It is far too early for anyone to decide they aren't able to get into any upper div cs courses.

2. Up until very recently, declared juniors were waitlisted for all upper div cs classes in phase 1 and only enrolled/moved off the waitlist in phase 2.  While the move to 13.5 units in phase 1 adds to that stress in unfortunate ways, I'd encourage people to not make any rash decisions.  It is likely the department will also find additional capacity for some of the upper div classes. (No, I don't know when.)

children.subject:
Not trying to be sassy or anything but just saying a couple of points 
Out of the 12 CS Upper Divs, 9 of them have reached the 70% limit. The two that have not are Software Engineering and Database systems both of which have zero according to Berkeley Time and the other is 170.

Out of the 14 EE/EECS upper divs, 4 have filled up completely. 

This is just in Phase 1. Many EECS/CS majors do finish their lower divs in the first three semesters and I don't know what they are supposed to do at this point. We can take EE classes but those are blocked by having to complete 105 and 120 for the most part and not everyone wants to do EE.

history.content:
Any advice for what to do if I can't enroll in any upper div classes? Anything I can take next semester is full and the wait list option is not available. Do I just take a semester off? 

Thanks
history.subject: Full Classes
